Award.AwardTitle: Mechanobiology of Asymmetric Myelin Membranes at Multiple Length Scales

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Myelin is a specialized membrane that acts as an insulator for axons (the connecting structure of nerve cells) and that allows the nerve signals to be transmitted quickly throughout the body. Despite the importance of this membrane to healthy nerve function, little is known about the structural dynamics or the interactions between the various molecules in the membrane. Improving this understanding will open up new strategies to better understand myelin-related diseases, such as multiple sclerosis, and potentially engineer ways to repair or replace damaged myelin. In addition to this societal impact, the research team will host an art show themed around nano-patterns and nano-structures related to myelin membranes as well as disseminate the knowledge through new graduate-level courses and to the broader public through connections established with Akron-area high school teachers.

It is hypothesized that relatively subtle changes in the composition of myelin lipids or proteins can significantly alter the phase behavior of the myelin system and the formation dynamics of lipid domains. These changes, in turn, lead to larger changes in membrane adhesion, rigidity, and integrity that can cause the myelin sheath to unravel and become dysfunctional. This hypothesis will be tested with advanced surface science techniques, including a surface force apparatus, a Langumuir trough coupled with fluorescence microscopy, and a streaming potential apparatus. The research will significantly advance the mechanistic understanding of how the lipids and proteins in the myelin membrane interact to affect the organization, fluidity, and rigidity of the myelin sheath.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project advanced our understanding of myelin membranes, the essential fatty insulating layers that surround nerve cells in the body. These membranes are critical for proper nerve function, and their breakdown is associated with serious neurological conditions, including multiple sclerosis and certain aspects of Alzheimer's disease. The project specifically investigated how the components of myelin membranes interact and organize, providing insights into why these protective layers sometimes fail.

The research team made several significant discoveries about the behavior of myelin membrane components. They found that cholesterol, a key building block of myelin, plays a critical role in influencing how other membrane components organize. Additionally, the team studied myelin basic proteins, which help hold the membrane together, discovering that these proteins can enhance the mixing of membrane components. Using advanced microscopy and measurement techniques, they observed how different parts of the membrane respond to pressure and temperature changes, offering new insights into membrane stability. These findings contribute to understanding how healthy myelin maintains its structure and function.

This work has both scientific and societal impact. Scientifically, it provides new fundamental knowledge about the physics and chemistry of biological membranes, furthering our understanding of these complex structures. On a societal level, the research holds promise for developing better treatments for diseases involving myelin damage. Multiple sclerosis alone affects approximately 400,000 people in the United States, with about 10,000 new cases diagnosed annually. By improving our understanding of how healthy myelin maintains its structure, researchers may uncover strategies to prevent or repair myelin damage in conditions like multiple sclerosis and Alzheimer's disease.

The project also offered valuable training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented groups in science, preparing the next generation of researchers in this critical field.

The research team is preparing several scientific publications to share their findings with the broader scientific community. The technical insights and experimental methods developed during this project will aid other researchers studying biological membranes and neurological diseases. This work lays a vital foundation for future studies aimed at developing new therapeutic approaches to treat myelin-related disorders.
